concepts.name: Dialectic
concepts.description: A method of philosophical argument that involves the exchange of logical arguments and counter-arguments, with the aim of resolving contradictions to reach closer approximations of truth.

attributes.description: The Socratic method is a form of dialectic
Dialectic relies on logical principles
Dialectic approaches stand in contrast to dogmatic ones

concepts.name: Socratic Method
concepts.description: A form of cooperative argumentative dialogue between individuals, based on asking and answering questions to stimulate critical thinking and draw out ideas and underlying assumptions.

attributes.description: The Socratic method is a specific form of dialectic
The Socratic method helps develop critical thinking

concepts.name: Virtue Ethics
concepts.description: An approach to ethics that emphasizes the virtues, or moral character, in contrast to theories that emphasize duties, rules, or the consequences of actions.

attributes.description: Virtue ethics focuses on character rather than rules
Virtue ethics focuses on character rather than outcomes
Virtue ethics aims at eudaimonia (flourishing)

concepts.name: Eudaimonia
concepts.description: A Greek term usually translated as happiness, welfare, or flourishing, referring to the highest human good and the aim of practical philosophy, including ethics and political philosophy.

attributes.description: Eudaimonia is the goal of virtue ethics
Eudaimonia is achieved through arete (excellence/virtue)

concepts.name: Arete
concepts.description: A Greek term referring to excellence or virtue, particularly of the kind that is associated with fulfilling one's purpose or function well.

attributes.description: Arete is a means to achieving eudaimonia
Arete is central to virtue ethics

concepts.name: Episteme
concepts.description: A Greek term for knowledge or understanding, particularly of a theoretical or abstract nature, contrasted with techne (craft knowledge) and phronesis (practical wisdom).

attributes.description: Episteme (knowledge) contrasts with doxa (opinion)
Episteme is theoretical knowledge versus technical knowledge
Episteme is theoretical knowledge versus practical wisdom

concepts.name: Phronesis
concepts.description: A Greek term for practical wisdom or prudence, the ability to know how to achieve the end goal of living well overall, acquired through experience and deliberation.

attributes.description: Phronesis is practical wisdom versus theoretical knowledge
Phronesis is central to virtue ethics
Phronesis enables good moral decision making

concepts.name: Aporia
concepts.description: A Greek term referring to a state of puzzlement or impasse, often deliberately induced in Socratic dialogue to expose contradictions in beliefs and to initiate deeper critical thinking.

attributes.description: Aporia is a crucial stage in the Socratic method
Aporia often precedes anamnesis (recollection) in Platonic dialogues

concepts.name: Elenchus
concepts.description: A Greek term for the central technique used in the Socratic method, involving a series of questions designed to test or refute a proposition or hypothesis.

attributes.description: Elenchus is the central technique of the Socratic method
Elenchus typically causes aporia (puzzlement)

concepts.name: Dialectical Materialism
concepts.description: A philosophical approach developed by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels that applies dialectic methods to understand material conditions and social change.

attributes.description: Dialectical materialism derives from dialectic
Dialectical materialism is a foundation of Marxism
